Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Computational population-genetic analysis for detection of soft selective sweeps
Award.AbstractNarration:
The molecular process of adaptation-the rise in frequency of genetic variants that enable organisms to succeed in their environments-is a central process in evolutionary biology. Surmounting significant challenges such as the ability of infectious agents to evolve resistance to drugs and the ability of crop pests to defeat a diverse array of increasingly powerful insecticides requires an understanding of the nature of adaptation. Recent advances have demonstrated that adaptation often occurs via "soft selective sweeps," in which an adaptive genetic variant originates multiple times or has become favored only after it has been present at a substantial frequency in the population. This project contributes to advancing knowledge of the fundamental evolutionary process of adaptation by developing new computational tools to detect and study the occurrence of adaptation by soft selective sweeps. Through the interactions of a multidisciplinary team spanning evolutionary biology and bioinformatics, the project integrates advances in evolutionary simulation with modern and efficient computational methods in order to produce progress on understanding adaptation, while simultaneously developing efficient computational tools applicable in the modern "big-data" era of inexpensive sequencing. In addition, its joint mentorship efforts from evolutionary and bioinformatics perspectives promote interdisciplinary training of graduate students and postdoctoral scientists.

The project has four objectives: (1) To design new tests for detecting selection in the case in which soft selective sweeps occur from standing genetic variation; (2) To identify haplotypes that carry a beneficial allele in genomic regions known to be experiencing positive selection; (3) To enhance new methods of analysis of natural selection to make them robust to confounding demographic scenarios; (4) To apply new selection methods in a series of data sets from multiple species, including humans, Drosophila, and Plasmodium malaria parasites. The project will use algorithmic techniques from combinatorial optimization and machine learning, and it will exploit ideas from population genetics and coalescent theory. It breaks ground on several fronts, providing a deeper understanding of the patterns in site-frequency spectra and haplotype data as a basis for selection signatures, and assisting in the design of subtyping studies for complex regions of the genome. As it becomes increasingly possible to sequence whole genomes of multiple individuals within a population, the intellectual challenge of designing tools for detecting selection to accommodate new phenomena such as soft sweeps coincides with the computational challenge of incorporating genomic data sets into selection studies. These challenges are addressed by the project, whose results will be available at http://proteomics.ucsd.edu/vbafna/research-2/nsf1458059/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes for grant NSF-DBI 1458557 2019-2020

Proposal Aims. The genetic signature of adaptation serves as a record of historical genetic events and contributes to an understanding of the evolutionary process and the genetic basis of phenotypes. While computational and experimental approaches to detecting selection-signatures have been heavily researched, profound gaps exist in our ability to detect selection via genomic analysis. A major issue relates to the frequency of the beneficial allele at the time of onset of positive selection. If a beneficial allele has an intermediate to high frequency at the time that a selective pressure becomes important, then different haplotypes carrying the favored allele can all increase in frequency. This soft selective sweep scenario?in contrast to a hard sweep of a single haplotype arising from a new mutation entering an existing selective setting?can potentially explain many observed selective events, but it results in weaker signals that are more challenging to detect. As it becomes increasingly possible to sequence whole genomes of multiple individuals within a population, the intellectual challenge of designing tools for detecting selection to accommodate new phenomena such as soft sweeps coincide with the computational challenge of incorporating genomic data sets into selection studies. The PIs address this challenge through the following goals.

Aim 1: Design a test for detecting selection in a soft-sweep regime arising due to standing variation.

Aim 2: Given a genomic region known to be experiencing positive selection, identify haplotypes that carry the beneficial allele.

Aim 3: Make tests in Aims 1 and 2 robust to confounding demographic regimes.

Aim 4: Apply the tests to assess selection in a series of data sets from multiple species, including human, Drosophila, and Plasmodium malaria parasites.

Major activities.

  • In the no-cost-extension period of the grant, we focused mainly on completing the experiments and manuscript preparation for assessing selection in asexual and sexual scenarios, specifically on different mechanisms of selective sweep in directed evolution, or ?evolve and re-sequence? studies using pooled time-series sequencing data. Specifically, we worked on a two decade long Drosophila experiment

Significant Results.

Paraphrasing from the abstract of our manuscript, ?to detect the genomic mechanisms underlying evolutionary dynamics of adaptation in sexually reproducing organisms, we analyzed multigenerational whole genome sequences of Drosophila melanogaster adapting to extreme O2 conditions over an experiment conducted for nearly two decades. We developed new methods to analyze time-series genomics data and predict adaptive mechanisms. We found a remarkable level of synchronicity in both hard and soft selective sweeps in replicate populations but also detected the arrival of favorable de novo mutations that constitute a few asynchronized sweeps. We additionally made direct experimental observations of rare recombination events that combined multiple alleles on to single, better-adapted haplotype. Based on the analyses of the genes in genomic intervals, we provide a deeper insight into the mechanisms of genome adaptation that allow complex organisms to survive harsh environments.?

 

Specifically, we made one of the first direct observations of the role of recombination in sexually reproducing populations on regions adapting to selection pressure. We call these events FM recombination events because they overcome the accumulation of deleterious mutations seen in asexual populations, an observation made independently by Fisher and Muller.

 

In a way, this manuscript is a summarization of the research aims of the grant. The manuscript has undergone one round of review for Nature Communications, and we have submitted a revision. Figures from the manuscript are attached below.

 

Intellectual Merit.  The project had considerable intellectual merit including the development of a pipeline ESAP, which is a fist of its kind effort to analyze time-series pooled genomic data to not only predict selective sweeps, but assign a mechanism to the mode of selection including a hard-sweep, soft-sweep with standing variation, hard sweep due to de novo mutation, and hard-sweep due to FM recombination, and show that under extreme O2 conditions, flies use all of these available mechanisms to adapt.

 

Broader Impact.  We have disseminated the results through our manuscript which is under revision. The project helped train Arya Iranmehr in 2019-2020, and he has graduated and took up a position at Human Longevity, where he is applying his skills to analyzing human genetic data and understanding the role of mutations in disease.
